terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Colombian mountains near Bogot√°. Significant elevation with mountain scenery at high altitude.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional Colombian event. Mountainous terrain with difficult access, high costs, high altitude, and regional field.

biased_opinion.summary: Gravel Bogot√° is a regional event in Colombia‚Äîmountainous terrain with significant elevation at high altitude. The Colombian mountains are impressive, but the difficult/expensive access, high altitude, and regional field keep it firmly in Tier 3.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A scenic Colombian mountain gravel race with altitude challenge. Worth it for adventure seekers with big budgets. Not practical for most riders.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you have a big budget and want a Colombian experience‚Äîmaybe. For most riders‚Äîthere are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better value: regional gravel races. For similar Colombian terrain: Gravel Medell√≠n.

logistics.food: Bogot√° has full dining options. Stock nutrition.

non_negotiables.why: High altitude (8000+ feet) requires altitude adaptation.

marketplace_variables.race_hook_detail: Regional event with mountainous terrain at altitude.

logistics.explanation: Registration opened January 1st but no information available on parking, packet pickup, start times, or local logistics for the May 24, 2026 debut. International travel to Ch√≠a with zero guidance on race weekend operations from organizers who run events across Brazil and Chile.

length.explanation: 80 miles hits the standard distance for UCI Gravel World Series events without being an ultra-endurance challenge. Long enough to create field separation and reward endurance, short enough that riders from different backgrounds can compete for Worlds qualification spots. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: Course details unpublished for the 2026 debut, but the Colombian highland terrain around Ch√≠a suggests technical gravel and climbing challenges. The region's elevation and geography imply surface variety beyond simple dirt roads. Similar technical demands to Gravel Worlds.

elevation.explanation: 8,000 feet of climbing over 80 miles averages 100 feet per mile, creating steady selection without extreme brutality. Respectable elevation gain that matches Colombian terrain expectations and will reward climbing strength throughout the race. Similar elevation profile to Gravel Worlds.

climate.explanation: May scheduling in Bogot√° targets dry season conditions, smart planning for the highland climate. No race-specific weather data available, but the region typically offers stable conditions during this period if altitude doesn't affect performance. Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL.

altitude.explanation: Starting at 2,564 meters (8,412 feet) in Ch√≠a makes this a serious high-altitude challenge that separates sea-level athletes immediately. The thin air creates a physiological hurdle most gravel races can't match, defining the entire race experience. Higher altitude racing, comparable to SBT GRVL.

adventure.explanation: Racing in the Colombian highlands near the historic 'Pueblo de la Luna' offers terrain most riders will never see otherwise. The combination of Muisca ceremonial grounds, colonial architecture, and high-altitude gravel creates adventure beyond typical race locations.

prestige.explanation: Part of the expanded 47-event UCI Gravel World Series offering Worlds qualification to top 25% finishers in each age group. Being among 16 new events added for South American growth is notable regionally, but it's a debut race with no competitive history.

race_quality.explanation: Organized by the team behind UCI events in Medell√≠n, Brazil, and Chile, suggesting operational experience across South American gravel racing. However, no published course details, aid station information, or cutoff times available for the May 2026 debut.

experience.explanation: Racing gravel in the shadow of Pe√±a de Juaica near historic Ch√≠a combines high-altitude challenge with cultural immersion. The setting blends pre-Columbian ceremonial sites with colonial architecture, creating a backdrop few gravel events can match.

community.explanation: Part of South American gravel expansion with the same organizers running events across the continent, building a regional network. UCI qualification format brings international riders to mix with Colombian gravel scene in an emerging market.

field_depth.explanation: Worlds qualification potential attracts serious competitors, but South American gravel fields typically run smaller than European or US events. The 2,564-meter starting elevation will limit international participation from sea-level-based athletes. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100. As Janosch Wintermantel puts it: "Stage 5 was a hot and mainly flat one. We wrestled the field down to 8 riders before entering the last few kilometres. The last 3 kilometres were then a crazy hunt in open traffic."

value.explanation: UCI Worlds qualification opportunity combined with access to unique Colombian highland terrain offers solid value proposition. No entry fees announced, but South American events typically price below European UCI races while delivering distinctive experiences.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $100-150. International flights to El Dorado Airport plus lodging near Ch√≠a with no logistical guidance creates expensive travel requirements. Getting to high-altitude Colombian gravel racing means significant costs for anyone outside South America, regardless of favorable peso exchange rates. More expensive than Atlas Mountain Race.
